bibl.title: Letter from Walter Reed to L. O. Howard, November 16, 1900

div1.p: Reed goes into great detail about the markings of the C. fasciatus and C. taeniatus species of mosquito. [Courtesy of the National Archives and Records Administration]

div1.head: Letter from Walter Reed to L. O. Howard, November 16, 1900
div1.opener:
THE NATIONAL ARCHIVES OF THE UNITED STATES
* 1934 *
THE NATIONAL ARCHIVES
Washington, D. C.
RECORDS OF THE BUREAU OF ENTOMOLOGY AND PLANT QUARANTINE.
Office of the Chief, Letters Received
Three Centimeters
Culex fasciatus fabs 1[male] 2[female]
DIVISION OF ENTOMOLOGY
* NOV 21 1900 *
Answered by Letter
Columbia Barracks;
Quemados, Cuba, Novr 16, 1900
Dear Mr Howard;
div1.p:
I have taken
the liberty of forwarding to
your address, by tomorrow's
mail, two small pill boxes,-
one containing a male and
female, C. fasciatus, & the other
a female C. taeniatus. These
come from Bayamo, Cuba.
Province of Santiago - I
hope that they will arrive
in good condition - I have
identified the male & female
fasciatus by the markings
(Stripes on mesonotum) and
have returned the diagnosis
of C. taeniatus by reason
THE NATIONAL ARCHIVES OF THE UNITED STATES
* 1934 *
THE NATIONAL ARCHIVES
Washington, D. C.
RECORDS OF THE BUREAU OF ENTOMOLOGY AND PLANT QUARANTINE.
Office of the Chief, Letters Received
Three Centimeters
of the absence of such stripes
on thorax (dorsum) of the female,
of course, the other points of
identification agree with
those given in your bulletin
no. 25.

upon consulting the table,
I do not find any points
of identification for the
male of C. taeniatus -
ofcourse the identification
of a member of the males
of other species areis also,
omitted from the table.

We find from larvae, now
hatching that both males
& females show the four stripes
of silvery scales on the back
mesonotum although this
is not mentioned as one
THE NATIONAL ARCHIVES OF THE UNITED STATES
* 1934 *
THE NATIONAL ARCHIVES
Washington, D. C.
RECORDS OF THE BUREAU OF ENTOMOLOGY AND PLANT QUARANTINE.
Office of the Chief, Letters Received
Three Centimeters
of the points of identification
for C. fasciatus (male) in your
table (p. 19). The stripes however
differ much in plainness, the two
outer being distinct & the
two inner stripes finer & [unclear]
use distinct - thus [unclear] Fin-
lay speaks of the workings
on the back of his mosquito
as resembling a lyre,
which is true of those we
are now calling C. fasciatus
of the specimens collected for
me from different parts of
the Island, this species
is largely in the majority.
Are we right in identify-
ing this as C. fasciatus?
Am very sorry to give
you so much trouble -
THE NATIONAL ARCHIVES OF THE UNITED STATES
* 1934 *
THE NATIONAL ARCHIVES
Washington, D. C.
RECORDS OF THE BUREAU OF ENTOMOLOGY AND PLANT QUARANTINE.
Office of the Chief, Letters Received
Three Centimeters
but will try to repay you
at some other time.

I send by this mail, also,
a Reprint of our Preliminary
Note, which I trust you
may find the time to
read.
div1.closer:
With best wishes,
very truly, yours, Walter Reed. Mr L. O. Howard,
Entomologist,
Dept. of Agriculture,
Washington, D.C.
[13 Dr. 2- R, Oct., 1899- Jan 1902]
